text: The issue can arise if manual adjustments are made or for other reasons the HQ and Store quantities get out of kilter. This can be rectified by performing a full item stock reconciliation. To do this open HQ manager and go to worksheets. Chose 501: Request a full item count. First step Click none to clear all and select the store you want to perform this for. Although multiple stores can be chosen on this worksheet, it is highly recommended doing them one at a time. 1. To avoid confusion 2. The second step explained later will be better served doing one at a time. Click Next You will see the following dialogue box. Ordinarily you can leave this as is and click next. Click Finish Check the details and click Approve. A worksheet will be created. Wait for the store to poll and process the worksheet, (Green flag). Once processed, no changes have been made. It has merely uploaded store quantities to the HQ but not made any changes to the inventory. The next step will allow the changes to be made. This is why it is advisable to do one store at a time. The next step needs to be performed before the store polls again. This is because the worksheet has uploaded quantities as they are now. Once the store polls again, any sales, returns or transfers will not be represented in the uploaded quantities. If you miss this window, the worksheet will need to be run again. Second step As stated earlier, the above worksheet must have been processed by the store. This step MUST be performed before the store polls again, unless they are currently not trading. Otherwise the quantities uploaded via the worksheet may no longer be correct, due to sales, returns or other inventory changes. HQ needs to be in maintenance mode. Go to wizards and select inventory wizard. Click Next Select task 190: Full item count reconciliation. Click Next Select the store you did the 501 worksheet for. You can check the box ( only show discrepancies). I have left it blank as there are no discrepancies on my test data. Click Next. Click Finish. A box will be displayed showing the discrepancies between the HQ and the uploaded store quantities. . Once you click commit HQ quantities will be changes to match the uploaded store quantities. It is not a bad idea to perform this periodically to make sure the data is correct.
title: HQ Inventory not matching store quantities
description:
The issue can arise if manual adjustments are made or for other reasons the HQ and Store quantities get out of kilter.


This can be rectified by performing a full item stock reconciliation.


To do this open HQ manager and go to worksheets. Chose 501: Request a full item count.


First step



Click none to clear all and select the store you want to perform this for.

Although multiple stores can be chosen on this worksheet, it is highly recommended doing them one at a time.

1. To avoid confusion

2. The second step explained later will be better served doing one at a time.

Click Next

You will see the following dialogue box.


Ordinarily you can leave this as is and click next.

Click Finish

Check the details and click Approve.


A worksheet will be created.



Wait for the store to poll and process the worksheet, (Green flag).


Once processed, no changes have been made. It has merely uploaded store quantities to the HQ but not made any changes to the inventory.

The next step will allow the changes to be made.


This is why it is advisable to do one store at a time.

The next step needs to be performed before the store polls again.

This is because the worksheet has uploaded quantities as they are now. 

Once the store polls again, any sales, returns or transfers will not be represented in the uploaded quantities.

If you miss this window, the worksheet will need to be run again.


Second step 


As stated earlier, the above worksheet must have been processed by the store.

This step MUST be performed before the store polls again, unless they are currently not trading.

Otherwise the quantities uploaded via the worksheet may no longer be correct, due to sales, returns or other inventory changes.


HQ needs to be in maintenance mode.


Go to wizards and select inventory wizard.



Click Next


Select task 190: Full item count reconciliation.


Click Next


Select the store you did the 501 worksheet for.


You can check the box ( only show discrepancies).

I have left it blank as there are no discrepancies on my test data.


Click Next.

 

Click Finish.


A box will be displayed showing the discrepancies between the HQ and the uploaded store quantities.

.



Once you click commit HQ quantities will be changes to match the uploaded store quantities.


It is not a bad idea to perform this periodically to make sure the data is correct.

text: Occasionally polling can stall, this results in no data being collected from the stores. The 402 (data upload) worksheet runs every time the store connects and processes sales, transfers as well as other data. If Polling has stalled you will notice that no sales data for the affected stores appear in reports. The first thing to check is that HQ server and Voucher server (if used) are both running and waiting for connection (green arrow). Next check that the worksheets are being processed. In H! manager Go To View / Worksheet status / Store status (as shown below). Flag symbols are as follows. White - unapproved, Green - completed, Blue - not completed but not due yet, Blue with yellow ! - Not processed but overdue. The Blue ones with an ! will be the ones that have not polled. The last polled date is shown. First try restarting HQ server by clicking file / exit on both HQ server and Voucher server. Or by ending HQserver.exe in Task Manager, NB (Voucher server is also HQserver.exe in TM). IMPORTANT!! HQ server must be started first, if voucher server is started first HQserver will return an error when starting and won't start. After restarting HQ and Voucher server and Voucher server check the status of worksheets again as above. If still not polling check HQclient in the stores is running and processing worksheets. In the stores HQclient will be running either on a Back Office PC or Till 1. HQ client looks like this. Check that worksheets 'completed with no errors'. Voucher server looks slightly different and doesn't process worksheets as such but facilitates global vouchers. When all completed and working Worksheet status looks like this.
title: Polling stalled
description:
Occasionally polling can stall, this results in no data being collected from the stores.

The 402 (data upload) worksheet runs every time the store connects and processes sales, transfers as well as other data.


If Polling has stalled you will notice that no sales data for the affected stores appear in reports.


The first thing to check is that HQ server and Voucher server (if used) are both running and waiting for connection (green arrow).


Next check that the worksheets are being processed.

In H! manager Go To View / Worksheet status / Store status (as shown below).



Flag symbols are as follows.

White - unapproved, Green - completed, Blue - not completed but not due yet, Blue with yellow ! - Not processed but overdue.


The Blue ones with an ! will be the ones that have not polled.

The last polled date is shown. 


First try restarting HQ server by clicking file / exit on both HQ server and Voucher server.

Or by ending HQserver.exe in Task Manager, NB (Voucher server is also HQserver.exe in TM).

IMPORTANT!! HQ server must be started first, if voucher server is started first HQserver will return an error when starting and won't start.


After restarting HQ and Voucher server and Voucher server check the status of worksheets again as above.

If still not polling check HQclient in the stores is running and processing worksheets.


In the stores HQclient will be running either on a  Back Office PC or Till 1.

HQ client looks like this.

Check that worksheets 'completed with no errors'.


Voucher server looks slightly different and doesn't process worksheets as such but facilitates global vouchers.


When all completed and working Worksheet status looks like this.

text: Oaktron I believe are the only customer on RMS using EDI via Clarks and software called LexiCom. The EDI files are sent through LexiCom between Oaktron and Clarks, the process is very similar to CFI with RMS as it handles the creation of new Clarks styles, stock takes and sales. EDI process runs on scheduled tasks on the back office machines at each location. The main machine being in Barcelona. The process on LexiCom require secure updated certificate files every 2 years. We are responsible for generating these certificates and there is a guide on doing so in the site files teams channel location. Clarks have to pay for these certificates before we generate them and upload them to LexiCom so make sure to speak with Emma Smith about the billing process. Recently Lexicom is no longer working for Oaktron as the certificates I generated no longer are supported security wise by Lexicom and to be able to generate the new version the latest version of Lexicom is required. However the new version no longer works on older Windows versions which Oaktron are running Windows 7. Sandra said they were going to work out on upgrading their machines and come back to us.
title: Oaktron EDI
description:
Oaktron I believe are the only customer on RMS using EDI via Clarks and software called LexiCom. 


The EDI files are sent through LexiCom between Oaktron and Clarks, the process is very similar to CFI with RMS as it handles the creation of new Clarks styles, stock takes and sales.


EDI process runs on scheduled tasks on the back office machines at each location. The main machine being in Barcelona. 


The process on LexiCom require secure updated certificate files every 2 years. We are responsible for generating these certificates and there is a guide on doing so in the site files teams channel location. Clarks have to pay for these certificates before we generate them and upload them to LexiCom so make sure to speak with Emma Smith about the billing process.


Recently Lexicom is no longer working for Oaktron as the certificates I generated no longer are supported security wise by Lexicom and to be able to generate the new version the latest version of Lexicom is required. However the new version no longer works on older Windows versions which Oaktron are running Windows 7. Sandra said they were going to work out on upgrading their machines and come back to us.

text: A: The custom POS buttons can be located and edited in Store Ops Manager, by following 'Database' - 'Registers' and you have multiple options such as keyboards, custom POS buttons and POS task pads that can all be edited.
title: Can you let me know where I go to edit the custom POS buttons?
description: A: The custom POS buttons can be located and edited in Store Ops Manager, by following 'Database' - 'Registers' and you have multiple options such as keyboards, custom POS buttons and POS task pads that can all be edited.

text: When the POS display setting is corrupted and the touchscreen keyboard moves under the transaction screen as below. To resolve this Hold down the CTRL + f6 the following window is displayed. Click on Transaction Screen tab and select window. Make a note of the height of the transaction window you will need this to set the top position of the touchscreen keyboard. Click Ok and select the touchscreen keyboard and click window. Set the top position to be the same as the height of the touchscreen keyboard. Click Ok Then ok again. You screen should be restored.
title: POS Display settings
description:
When the POS display setting is corrupted and the touchscreen keyboard moves under the transaction screen as below.




To resolve this Hold down the CTRL + f6 the following window is displayed.



Click on Transaction Screen tab and select window. Make a note of the height of the transaction window you will need this to set the top position of the touchscreen keyboard.




Click Ok and select the touchscreen keyboard and click window.

Set the top position to be the same as the height of the touchscreen keyboard.





Click Ok Then ok again. You screen should be restored.

text: Attempt to process COM object 'RSG_ILINK.clsCardAuth' failed. An unknown error occurred. When trying to process a card transaction you get the following. The first thing to try is to exit and restart POS. In most cases this will resolve the issue. If that fails there may be an issue with the dll or the dll is no registered. In which case contact K3 support.
title: Attempt to process COM object RSG_ILINK
description:
Attempt to process COM object 'RSG_ILINK.clsCardAuth' failed. An unknown error occurred.



When trying to process a card transaction you get the following.



The first thing to try is to exit and restart POS.

In most cases this will resolve the issue.


If that fails there may be an issue with the dll or the dll is no registered.

In which case contact K3 support.

text: When an RMS till goes into offline mode, the current batch is Blind Closed by the system. If the till is used in offline mode the these transactions go into a separate batch in the offline database. When the till is back online (reconnected to the primary database), this batch too is uploaded to the server and blind closed. The transaction from that point forward go into a new (3rd) batch and trading continues as normal. When you come to Z read at the end of the day only the transactions from the point the database was reconnected will show (3rd batch). In order to balance the till, it will be necessary to X and Z read these blind closed batches. To do this follow the following instructions. First of all exit POS, this is because POS holds the printer and the X and Z reads will not print if the printer is help on to by POS. Open SO manager. Go to Journal / Update batch info. Click OK on the dialogue box that appears, there is no need to enter any filters. Find Blind Closed batches in the list. The below image only shows open batches as I do not have any blind closed batches currently. Open batches are current batches being worked, these can not be X or Z read here. To process the batches Double click on the batch number. This will bring up the options below. Whether you need to enter Opening and Closing amounts depends on your current settings. When you have Z read all of the batches for the day in question. These Z reads can be added to the totals from the main Z read to balance the till. Please remember that if POS is still open and you process the Z read, the Z read will not print but it will process the bacth and it will no longer be available in this list. There is nothing we can do to get it back, so please make sure POS is exited before this process is undertaken.
title: Offline batches -Blind Closed
description:
When an RMS till goes into offline mode, the current batch is Blind Closed by the system.


If the till is used in offline mode the these transactions go into a separate batch in the offline database.


When the till is back online (reconnected to the primary database), this batch too is uploaded to the server and blind closed.


The transaction from that point forward go into a new (3rd) batch and trading continues as normal.


When you come to Z read at the end of the day only the transactions from the point the database was reconnected will show (3rd batch).


In order to balance the till, it will be necessary to X and Z read these blind closed batches.


To do this follow the following instructions.


First of all exit POS, this is because POS holds the printer and the X and Z reads will not print if the printer is help on to by POS.

Open SO manager.

Go to Journal / Update batch info.



Click OK on the dialogue box that appears, there is no need to enter any filters.




Find Blind Closed batches in the list.

The below image only shows open batches as I do not have any blind closed batches currently.

Open batches are current batches being worked, these can not be X or Z read here.


To process the batches Double click on the batch number.

This will bring up the options below.

Whether you need to enter Opening and Closing amounts depends on your current settings. 



When you have Z read all of the batches for the day in question.

These Z reads can be added to the totals from the main Z read to balance the till.


Please remember that if POS is still open and you process the Z read, the Z read will not print but it will process the bacth and it will no longer be available in this list.

There is nothing we can do to get it back, so please make sure POS is exited before this process is undertaken.

text: Cinders require an update to one of their reports every year to allow the new seasons to show in their customer Value list report. This requires you adding some lines to the report file via Notepad++ As you can see from the below formula there is a pattern that needs to be followed to allow the report to run correctly. Other parts of the report file will need to be updated to the new season name. eg SS2026 You need to save the file as a new qrp and upload it to the RMS reports folder for HQ. A copy of the latest reports have been sent to Thomas Toulouse.
title: Cinders Reports
description:
Cinders require an update to one of their reports every year to allow the new seasons to show in their customer Value list report. 


This requires you adding some lines to the report file via Notepad++ 


As you can see from the below formula there is a pattern that needs to be followed to allow the report to run correctly.




Other parts of the report file will need to be updated to the new season name. eg SS2026


You need to save the file as a new qrp and upload it to the RMS reports folder for HQ. A copy of the latest reports have been sent to Thomas Toulouse.

text: If a customer has logged a case regarding the POS or onscreen keyboard not showing correctly on the screen. This could be a case that the windows position or size is incorrect. One way of changing the size is by using CTRL + F6 where a screen menu will pop up. If CTRL + F6 does not work, you maybe find a screen button on the POS that also allows you to see this menu. In this menu there will be options for changing the transaction screen and an option for the onscreen keyboard. By editing the Position and the Size, you will be able to correct the positions of the POS and one screen keyboard. Once you have made your changes click OK for these to take effect.
title: POS keyboard no longer showing
description:
If a customer has logged a case regarding the POS or onscreen keyboard not showing correctly on the screen. This could be a case that the windows position or size is incorrect.


One way of changing the size is by using CTRL + F6 where a screen menu will pop up. If CTRL + F6 does not work, you maybe find a screen button on the POS that also allows you to see this menu.


In this menu there will be options for changing the transaction screen and an option for the onscreen keyboard. By editing the Position and the Size, you will be able to correct the positions of the POS and one screen keyboard. Once you have made your changes click OK for these to take effect.

text: RMSify is a Shopify add-in developed and supported by K3 BTG, and is designed to provide a full integration between Microsoft Dynamics RMS, and the popular eCommerce platform, Shopify. The add-in must be installed through the Shopify App Store, and you must have a valid Shopify account in order to install it. It’s easily found by searching for “RMSify” at http://apps.shopify.com. RMSify makes it easy for retailers using Microsoft Dynamics RMS to start trading online without the expense and risk associated with fully integrated solutions. RMSify can be installed quickly and easily, and configured with a minimal amount of fuss, all without the need for an expensive consultant, or detailed technical knowledge of RMS or Shopify. If you can use RMS, you can use RMSify. Using RMSify means you have total integration of your products across your sales channels.
title: What is RMSify?
description:
RMSify is a Shopify add-in developed and supported by K3 BTG, and is designed to provide a full integration between Microsoft Dynamics RMS, and the popular eCommerce platform, Shopify. The add-in must be installed through the Shopify App Store, and you must have a valid Shopify account in order to install it. It’s easily found by searching for “RMSify” at http://apps.shopify.com.


RMSify makes it easy for retailers using Microsoft Dynamics RMS to start trading online without the expense and risk associated with fully integrated solutions. RMSify can be installed quickly and easily, and configured with a minimal amount of fuss, all without the need for an expensive consultant, or detailed technical knowledge of RMS or Shopify. If you can use RMS, you can use RMSify. Using RMSify means you have total integration of your products across your sales channels.

text: RMSify is a Shopify add-in developed and supported by K3 BTG, and is designed to provide a full integration between Microsoft Dynamics RMS, and the popular eCommerce platform, Shopify. The add-in must be installed through the Shopify App Store, and you must have a valid Shopify account in order to install it. It’s easily found by searching for “RMSify” at http://apps.shopify.com The software itself is a single installer which can be used anywhere in the RMS estate. There are no different installers for Headquarters, Store or POS as there are with other integrated solutions. It’s one simple package which can be installed wherever you need to run it. The package consists of 2 components. RMSify Sync – This is the application which synchronises your product data between RMS and Shopify, and is also where all settings are configured. RMSify Sync can either synchronise data from RMS to Shopify, or the other way round – from Shopify into RMS. This can be run on a Store Operations database or a Headquarters database and it will automatically detect which it is and behave accordingly. This is usually operated from a “Back office” computer. RMSify Web Orders – This is the application which runs on the till and allows the process of Shopify Web Orders through the RMS POS interface. It retrieves outstanding orders from Shopify to allow a “Picking List” to be printed to your receipt printer. Once picked, it imports the order as a standard POS transaction and allows you to tender the transaction as per RMS. It then notifies Shopify that the order has been shipped. It can only be launched through a Custom POS Button and therefore can only be run on an RMS Point of Sale. As already discussed, RMSify can be used in Store Operations and Headquarters, or a combination of both. Here are the supported topologies which you can deploy RMSify to. Standard Headquarters – This scenario is when product data is synchronising from the Headquarters database. All web orders must be processed through an RMS POS, and you must choose which store is going to be used to process your web orders. You can optionally choose which “on hand” figures you want to use in Shopify – Either the quantities from the store you selected as your web store or the total of “on hand” quantities from all of your stores. In this scenario, it is not possible to run Sync and Web Orders on the same physical computer. Store Only Headquarters – This scenario is when your store is part of an RMS Headquarters chain, but product data and web orders are all processed through a single store as part of that chain. This is not recommended, as any product data amended at store level is liable to be overwritten by an RMS Headquarters Worksheet. In this scenario, only local store inventory data is used for your Shopify inventory levels. Single Store – This scenario is when you have only one RMS store. Both RMSify Sync and RMSify Web Orders run from the single store database.
title: RMSify Introduction
description:
RMSify is a Shopify add-in developed and supported by K3 BTG, and is designed to provide a full integration between Microsoft Dynamics RMS, and the popular eCommerce platform, Shopify. The add-in must be installed through the Shopify App Store, and you must have a valid Shopify account in order to install it. It’s easily found by searching for “RMSify” at http://apps.shopify.com 


The software itself is a single installer which can be used anywhere in the RMS estate. There are no different installers for Headquarters, Store or POS as there are with other integrated solutions. It’s one simple package which can be installed wherever you need to run it. The package consists of 2 components. 


  • RMSify Sync – This is the application which synchronises your product data between RMS and Shopify, and is also where all settings are configured. RMSify Sync can either synchronise data from RMS to Shopify, or the other way round – from Shopify into RMS. This can be run on a Store Operations database or a Headquarters database and it will automatically detect which it is and behave accordingly. This is usually operated from a “Back office” computer. 


  • RMSify Web Orders – This is the application which runs on the till and allows the process of Shopify Web Orders through the RMS POS interface. It retrieves outstanding orders from Shopify to allow a “Picking List” to be printed to your receipt printer. Once picked, it imports the order as a standard POS transaction and allows you to tender the transaction as per RMS. It then notifies Shopify that the order has been shipped. It can only be launched through a Custom POS Button and therefore can only be run on an RMS Point of Sale. 

 

As already discussed, RMSify can be used in Store Operations and Headquarters, or a combination of both. Here are the supported topologies which you can deploy RMSify to. 


  • Standard Headquarters – This scenario is when product data is synchronising from the Headquarters database. All web orders must be processed through an RMS POS, and you must choose which store is going to be used to process your web orders. You can optionally choose which “on hand” figures you want to use in Shopify – Either the quantities from the store you selected as your web store or the total of “on hand” quantities from all of your stores. In this scenario, it is not possible to run Sync and Web Orders on the same physical computer. 


  • Store Only Headquarters – This scenario is when your store is part of an RMS Headquarters chain, but product data and web orders are all processed through a single store as part of that chain. This is not recommended, as any product data amended at store level is liable to be overwritten by an RMS Headquarters Worksheet. In this scenario, only local store inventory data is used for your Shopify inventory levels. 


  • Single Store – This scenario is when you have only one RMS store. Both RMSify Sync and RMSify Web Orders run from the single store database.

text: During the synchronisation in either direction, the Log section gives you some really useful information as to what is going on with the sync you are attempting There are 3 types of log message, indicated by the icon. Success: This indicates that something has happened successfully. For example, a product has been successfully uploaded, or a product has been updated for. Warning: This informational message alerts you that something has changed which you need to be aware of, or something has been uploaded that you need to consider as it may not be right. An example of this might be a product which has been uploaded with a Zero price, or informing you that one of the synchronization rules have changed. Error: This means something during the synchronization has failed. Usually, these errors will tell you what the fault is so you can correct them. This may be that it was unable to connect to Shopify, or perhaps that an image failed to upload due to it already being in use for another product.
title: I am seeing error messages in the sync log, what do they mean?
description:
During the synchronisation in either direction, the Log section gives you some really useful information as to what is going on with the sync you are attempting 


There are 3 types of log message, indicated by the icon.



Success: This indicates that something has happened successfully. For example, a product has been successfully uploaded, or a product has been updated for. 


Warning: This informational message alerts you that something has changed which you need to be aware of, or something has been uploaded that you need to consider as it may not be right. An example of this might be a product which has been uploaded with a Zero price, or informing you that one of the synchronization rules have changed. 


Error: This means something during the synchronization has failed. Usually, these errors will tell you what the fault is so you can correct them. This may be that it was unable to connect to Shopify, or perhaps that an image failed to upload due to it already being in use for another product.

text: RMSify allows you to automatically create transactions for Shopify Web Orders in RMS. When enabled, you must ensure that RMSify Automatic Web Orders is running on your Web Store POS. When running, Auto Web Orders will check for new orders from your Shopify store every 5 minutes. When an order meets the set criteria (i.e. Fulfilled/Paid) RMSify will automatically create a corresponding transaction in your RMS database for the Web Order. This setting gives you the flexibility of allowing you to fulfil your orders through the Shopify admin panel but still track and amend stock in your RMS system to ensure inventory levels are as accurate as possible. This setting can be enabled in the RMSify Sync Settings under the rules tab and enabling "Automatically Create RMS Transactions": Once enabled, you'll need to decide when you want RMSify to create the transactions by setting the "Create Transactions When" option: When set to Fulfilled, RMSify will automatically create a transaction in RMS as soon as you mark the order as fulfilled in Shopify. RMSify will still commit stock on orders that haven't yet been fulfilled and committed stock will be released when the transaction is created in RMS. When set to Paid, RMSify will automatically create a transaction in RMS as soon as the order in Shopify is marked as Paid. Stock will typically not be committed in this instance as orders will typically come through as 'Paid' immediately. This means that the transaction will be created almost instantly and instead of being set to committed, the stock will be removed from your on-hand quantities You'll also need to select your preferred cashier to be assigned to the transactions in RMS. This drop-down will list all cashiers listed in your RMS database. Finally, you can specify a register for the transactions to be created against. Web Order Transactions will be posted into the currently open batch on the specified register. When enabling this setting in a HQ environment, RMSify will automatically create #51 Worksheets to update your nominated Web Stores settings. You'll need to ensure these worksheets are processed to ensure Auto Transactions is enabled at the Store level. Like Transactions, you also have the option of automatically creating returns. Auto returns will identify any orders that have been refunded or partially refunded and process a corresponding return in RMS. Important note: When this setting is enabled, the stock for any refunds will be sent back to your on-hand quantities. If you aren't receiving the stock back you'll need to ensure to manually adjust the stock accordingly. Auto Transactions can be enabled without Auto Refunds but Auto Refunds CANNOT be enabled without Auto Transactions. If you wish to create automatic refunds RMSify will also create automatic transactions.
title: Automatically Create RMS Transactions
description:
RMSify allows you to automatically create transactions for Shopify Web Orders in RMS. When enabled, you must ensure that RMSify Automatic Web Orders is running on your Web Store POS. When running, Auto Web Orders will check for new orders from your Shopify store every 5 minutes. When an order meets the set criteria (i.e. Fulfilled/Paid) RMSify will automatically create a corresponding transaction in your RMS database for the Web Order.


This setting gives you the flexibility of allowing you to fulfil your orders through the Shopify admin panel but still track and amend stock in your RMS system to ensure inventory levels are as accurate as possible.


This setting can be enabled in the RMSify Sync Settings under the rules tab and enabling "Automatically Create RMS Transactions":

Once enabled, you'll need to decide when you want RMSify to create the transactions by setting the "Create Transactions When" option:

  • When set to Fulfilled, RMSify will automatically create a transaction in RMS as soon as you mark the order as fulfilled in Shopify. 
    • RMSify will still commit stock on orders that haven't yet been fulfilled and committed stock will be released when the transaction is created in RMS.
  • When set to Paid, RMSify will automatically create a transaction in RMS as soon as the order in Shopify is marked as Paid.
    • Stock will typically not be committed in this instance as orders will typically come through as 'Paid' immediately. This means that the transaction will be created almost instantly and instead of being set to committed, the stock will be removed from your on-hand quantities


You'll also need to select your preferred cashier to be assigned to the transactions in RMS. This drop-down will list all cashiers listed in your RMS database.


Finally, you can specify a register for the transactions to be created against. Web Order Transactions will be posted into the currently open batch on the specified register.


When enabling this setting in a HQ environment, RMSify will automatically create #51 Worksheets to update your nominated Web Stores settings. You'll need to ensure these worksheets are processed to ensure Auto Transactions is enabled at the Store level.


Like Transactions, you also have the option of automatically creating returns. Auto returns will identify any orders that have been refunded or partially refunded and process a corresponding return in RMS. Important note: When this setting is enabled, the stock for any refunds will be sent back to your on-hand quantities. If you aren't receiving the stock back you'll need to ensure to manually adjust the stock accordingly.

Auto Transactions can be enabled without Auto Refunds but Auto Refunds CANNOT be enabled without Auto Transactions. If you wish to create automatic refunds RMSify will also create automatic transactions.

text: Auto Web Orders is a critical part of RMSify and must be running in the background as often as possible. Auto Web Orders starts up by default when you first click on the Get Web Orders button on the POS. However, you may wish for this to be started up automatically, for example if you're using the Automatic Transactions process or perhaps don't open the Web Orders UI that frequently but still wish for RMSify to be reading your orders to commit stock in RMS. To set up a scheduled task to run Auto Web Orders do the following: Search for Task Scheduler in your Windows Start Menu, open it and navigate to your Task Scheduler Library. On the right-hand side click on "Create Task": In the form that opens up, give the task a suitable name and tick the "Run with highest Privileges" box: Navigate to the "Triggers" tab. Here click "New..." and change the "Begin the task" option to "At log on": Please note that users will be required to have admin privileges in order to run Auto Web Orders. If you have users set up that don't have admin rights then you may wish to select a specific user rather than any user. Next, click on the actions tab and create a new action. From here, select "Start a program" and browse to your RMSify install path and select "RMSifyAutomaticWebOrders.exe": The default install path for RMSify is "C:\Program Files (x86)\K3 Retail\RMSify\RMSifyAutomaticWebOrders.exe" Press OK to come out of all menus and your task will be created. You can test that the scheduled task is working by attempting to run it manually and confirming the process is running in Task Manager.
title: Using Windows Task Scheduler to Start Auto Web Orders
description:
Auto Web Orders is a critical part of RMSify and must be running in the background as often as possible. Auto Web Orders starts up by default when you first click on the Get Web Orders button on the POS. However, you may wish for this to be started up automatically, for example if you're using the Automatic Transactions process or perhaps don't open the Web Orders UI that frequently but still wish for RMSify to be reading your orders to commit stock in RMS.


To set up a scheduled task to run Auto Web Orders do the following:

  • Search for Task Scheduler in your Windows Start Menu, open it and navigate to your Task Scheduler Library.
  • On the right-hand side click on "Create Task":
  • In the form that opens up, give the task a suitable name and tick the "Run with highest Privileges" box:
  • Navigate to the "Triggers" tab. Here click "New..." and change the "Begin the task" option to "At log on":
    • Please note that users will be required to have admin privileges in order to run Auto Web Orders. If you have users set up that don't have admin rights then you may wish to select a specific user rather than any user.
  • Next, click on the actions tab and create a new action. From here, select "Start a program" and browse to your RMSify install path and select "RMSifyAutomaticWebOrders.exe":
    • The default install path for RMSify is "C:\Program Files (x86)\K3 Retail\RMSify\RMSifyAutomaticWebOrders.exe"
  • Press OK to come out of all menus and your task will be created.


You can test that the scheduled task is working by attempting to run it manually and confirming the process is running in Task Manager.

text: The error message below can appear when you try to sync newly created web items from RMS but have custom fields via quick editor blank. If you're using custom fields in RMSify, please ensure you have filled in the custom fields with data and then run the sync again. The reason the error is displayed is due to RMSify trying to create new items with blank data for the fields which in turn makes RMSify thing these items will be duplicates on Shopify.
title: Duplicate error when syncing
description:
The error message below can appear when you try to sync newly created web items from RMS but have custom fields via quick editor blank.


If you're using custom fields in RMSify, please ensure you have filled in the custom fields with data and then run the sync again. The reason the error is displayed is due to RMSify trying to create new items with blank data for the fields which in turn makes RMSify thing these items will be duplicates on Shopify.

text: Sometimes you may be required to set a custom running time for your RMSify Automatic Stock Updates. Since the function of the stock sync is to update Shopify with stock sold in your brick and mortar store it is best practice to run your Stock Updates during trading hours only or if in a HQ environment, only for the duration that your Stock Source stores are polling. By default RMSify only allows you to pick from certain timing options for your schedule: You can change the timings more granularly by editing the Scheduled Task itself in Windows Task Scheduler. To do this: Open Windows Task Scheduler. Find your RMSify Stock sync (this should be called "RMSify_StockUpdate") and double-click into it to open the proerties. Navigate to the 'Triggers' tab and edit the current trigger: Set your start time to be your opening time: Enable the 'Repeat Task every:' option and set the frequency to your desired amount: When selecting a duration you'll notice the drop-down only includes set amounts. You can add any duration you wish by simply typing into the text field. It may be tempting to run the schedule as frequently as possible. However, this can actually be detrimental. Best practice when choosing a frequency when running in an RMS HQ environment is to match your 401 worksheet frequency. This ensures HQ has the latest stock figures and isn't updating Shopify unnecessarily. Another consideration is the amount of items included in the stock sync. Typically we would recommend not running your stock sync more frequently than 1 hour. In the below example our trading hours would be 09:00 - 18:00 and the stock sync will run on the hour, every hour between those times: Click 'OK' on all open windows to save your changes.
title: Setting a Custom Schedule for Automatic Stock Update
description:
Sometimes you may be required to set a custom running time for your RMSify Automatic Stock Updates. Since the function of the stock sync is to update Shopify with stock sold in your brick and mortar store it is best practice to run your Stock Updates during trading hours only or if in a HQ environment, only for the duration that your Stock Source stores are polling.


By default RMSify only allows you to pick from certain timing options for your schedule:


You can change the timings more granularly by editing the Scheduled Task itself in Windows Task Scheduler. To do this:

  1. Open Windows Task Scheduler.
  2. Find your RMSify Stock sync (this should be called "RMSify_StockUpdate") and double-click into it to open the proerties.
  3. Navigate to the 'Triggers' tab and edit the current trigger:
  4. Set your start time to be your opening time: 
  5.  Enable the 'Repeat Task every:' option and set the frequency to your desired amount: 
    • When selecting a duration you'll notice the drop-down only includes set amounts. You can add any duration you wish by simply typing into the text field.
    • It may be tempting to run the schedule as frequently as possible. However, this can actually be detrimental. Best practice when choosing a frequency when running in an RMS HQ environment is to match your 401 worksheet frequency. This ensures HQ has the latest stock figures and isn't updating Shopify unnecessarily. Another consideration is the amount of items included in the stock sync. Typically we would recommend not running your stock sync more frequently than 1 hour.
  6. In the below example our trading hours would be 09:00 - 18:00 and the stock sync will run on the hour, every hour between those times: 
  7. Click 'OK' on all open windows to save your changes.

text: RMSify can be launched from the Start Menu through Start > All Programs > Retail Technology Ltd > RMSify, or if you are using the standard RMS addins path, it will be accessible through Utilities > Addins > RMSify in Store Operations or Headquarters Manager. These will always launch the main RMSify application, which is known as RMSify Sync and is shown below. Additionally, there is an application called RMSify Web Orders, and can only be opened through a “Custom POS Button” on the POS. This button is automatically created upon the launch of RMSify Sync. This is shown below.
title: How to Launch RMSify
description:
RMSify can be launched from the Start Menu through Start > All Programs > Retail Technology Ltd > RMSify, or if you are using the standard RMS addins path, it will be accessible through Utilities > Addins > RMSify in Store Operations or Headquarters Manager.


These will always launch the main RMSify application, which is known as RMSify Sync and is shown below.

 


Additionally, there is an application called RMSify Web Orders, and can only be opened through a “Custom POS Button” on the POS. This button is automatically created upon the launch of RMSify Sync. This is shown below.

text: The menus allow you to access various tools and functions within the application. File > Database Settings This will let you switch between RMS databases File > Exit This will exit the application Options > Settings This will take you to the settings screen to configure the software Options > Backup Database This will backup the database the application is using Options > Require Login This will toggle if you are required to log in to the app or not Updates > Check For Updates This will update the software to the latest version Tools > Scheduled Stock Updates This will allow you to schedule an automatic stock quantity update Tools > Multiple Web Stores This is where you configure RMSify to update multiple web stores Tools > Web Item Filter This is where you can filter what items get published to the web Tools > Custom Fields This is where you define custom fields to extend your database Tools > Quick Editor This is where you make quick wholesale changes to your database Tools > Print Logs This will print the log from the user interface to help troubleshoot Tools > Delete All Custom Collections This will delete all custom collections from your Shopify store Tools > Delete All Images This will delete all images from your Shopify store Help > About This will tell you the software’s current version number Help > Read Manual This will open this user guide (PDF Reader required) Help > Send Logs This is used by K3 support if we need to troubleshoot the software Help > Support Forum This is a link to our support forum to get free help with the software
title: Menus Explained
description:
The menus allow you to access various tools and functions within the application.


File > Database Settings
This will let you switch between RMS databases
File > Exit
This will exit the application
Options > Settings
This will take you to the settings screen to configure the software
Options > Backup Database
This will backup the database the application is using
Options > Require Login
This will toggle if you are required to log in to the app or not
Updates > Check For Updates
This will update the software to the latest version
Tools > Scheduled Stock Updates
This will allow you to schedule an automatic stock quantity update
Tools > Multiple Web Stores
This is where you configure RMSify to update multiple web stores
Tools > Web Item Filter
This is where you can filter what items get published to the web
Tools > Custom Fields
This is where you define custom fields to extend your database
Tools > Quick Editor
This is where you make quick wholesale changes to your database
Tools > Print Logs
This will print the log from the user interface to help troubleshoot
Tools > Delete All Custom Collections
This will delete all custom collections from your Shopify store
Tools > Delete All ImagesThis will delete all images from your Shopify store
Help > About
This will tell you the software’s current version number
Help > Read Manual
This will open this user guide (PDF Reader required)
Help > Send Logs
This is used by K3 support if we need to troubleshoot the software
Help > Support Forum
This is a link to our support forum to get free help with the software

text: Status The status bar shows you the current sync status of the application. When Idle (As above) or complete, you can Sync data. Whilst data syncing is in progress, you will see a progress bar for each section of the sync that it has to perform. Each of these are detailed later in the user guide. Log The log section of the screen shows you useful information about the sync process, allowing you to see exactly what is happening during data synchronisation. If you double click an error in the log, it will show you the full details of the error, which can often be much more helpful when deducing the cause of the issue or warning. If you need to send these log files to K3 for analysis, then use the Help > Send Logs menu. Sync Section This area lists the different Shopify fields which RMS can sync with. These make use of the field mappings which are defined in the configuration. At any time you can see what field is mapped to it by hovering the pointer over the field name. To Shopify This column allows you to pick which fields you want to update in Shopify when you press the Sync button. It will only update fields in Shopify which have a check in the box. Cells which are shaded out are “required” fields that you can not toggle, so will always synchronise with Shopify. From Shopify This column allows you to synchronise data back from Shopify into RMS when you press the sync button. It is designed so that you can make the most of Shopify’s WYSIWYG editor and apply rich formatting to your product description and product pages. Cells which are shaded out are “required” fields that you can not toggle, so will always synchronise with Shopify. Sync Buttons When one of the relevant Sync buttons is pressed, data will be syncronised between RMS and Shopify in the direction that you choose. Only fields which have a check in the box will be synchronised. They will only synchronise new or changed data. Go To Webstore This button takes you directly to the administration area of your Shopify web store. You will still need to log in using your registered username and password. If you are using the Multiple Web Stores feature, the button will take you to the administration page of the webstore selected in the Sync drop down box. Choose Web Store If you are using the Multiple Web Stores feature, then the Sync screen has a drop down box listing the web stores you have configured. Pressing the Sync button will sync data for the web store selected in this box only.
title: User Interface
description:
Status

The status bar shows you the current sync status of the application.

When Idle (As above) or complete, you can Sync data.

Whilst data syncing is in progress, you will see a progress bar for each section of the sync that it has to perform. Each of these are detailed later in the user guide.

 

Log

The log section of the screen shows you useful information about the sync process, allowing you to see exactly what is happening during data synchronisation.

If you double click an error in the log, it will show you the full details of the error, which can often be much more helpful when deducing the cause of the issue or warning.

If you need to send these log files to K3 for analysis, then use the Help > Send Logs menu.

 

Sync Section

This area lists the different Shopify fields which RMS can sync with. These make use of the field mappings which are defined in the configuration. At any time you can see what field is mapped to it by hovering the pointer over the field name.

 

To Shopify

This column allows you to pick which fields you want to update in Shopify when you press the Sync button. It will only update fields in Shopify which have a check in the box.

Cells which are shaded out are “required” fields that you can not toggle, so will always synchronise with Shopify.

 

From Shopify

This column allows you to synchronise data back from Shopify into RMS when you press the sync button. It is designed so that you can make the most of Shopify’s WYSIWYG editor and apply rich formatting to your product description and product pages.

Cells which are shaded out are “required” fields that you can not toggle, so will always synchronise with Shopify. 

 

Sync Buttons

When one of the relevant Sync buttons is pressed, data will be syncronised between RMS and Shopify in the direction that you choose. Only fields which have a check in the box will be synchronised.

They will only synchronise new or changed data.


Go To Webstore

This button takes you directly to the administration area of your Shopify web store. You will still need to log in using your registered username and password.

 

If you are using the Multiple Web Stores feature, the button will take you to the administration page of the webstore selected in the Sync drop down box. 

Choose Web Store

If you are using the Multiple Web Stores feature, then the Sync screen has a drop down box listing the web stores you have configured.

Pressing the Sync button will sync data for the web store selected in this box only.

text: This section lists all of the web orders which have been downloaded to RMS and are awaiting picking and processing. With an order selected you can perform a task with the buttons at the bottom of the screen. Order Name The Shopify order name downloaded (Usually an order number) Order Date The date the order was created on Shopify RMS Customer Name The name of the RMS customer that the order is for Shopify Billing Name The name of the customer downloaded from Shopify Order Value The total value of the order (Including shipping) Status If the order has been picked or not Risk If the order is at risk of being fraudulent it will show a yellow icon The RMS Customer and Shopify Billing Name can be different. The Shopify Billing Name is the name of the customer as entered into the web order. When downloading web orders, it associates the order with the RMS customer which has a matching Account Number or Email Address. Any cashier which needs to process web orders must have the permission to alter tax status in their RMS cashier rights. For more information about this, please contact your RMS support partner.
title: Web Orders
description:
This section lists all of the web orders which have been downloaded to RMS and are awaiting picking and processing. With an order selected you can perform a task with the buttons at the bottom of the screen.

 

Order NameThe Shopify order name downloaded (Usually an order number)
Order DateThe date the order was created on Shopify
RMS Customer NameThe name of the RMS customer that the order is for
Shopify Billing NameThe name of the customer downloaded from Shopify
Order ValueThe total value of the order (Including shipping)
StatusIf the order has been picked or not
RiskIf the order is at risk of being fraudulent it will show a yellow icon

 


The RMS Customer and Shopify Billing Name can be different. The Shopify Billing Name is the name of the     customer as entered into the web order. When downloading web orders, it associates the order with the RMS customer which has a matching Account Number or Email Address.


Any cashier which needs to process web orders must have the permission to alter tax status in their RMS cashier rights. For more information about this, please contact your RMS support partner.

text: Pressing this button will retrieve all “Open” web orders in groups of 20 from your Shopify web store, where a payment has either been “Authorised” or “Captured”. The application will automatically connect to Shopify and download orders when the Web Orders button is pressed in the POS, so there is no need to click the Web Orders button and then immediately click the Get Web Orders button. If you have more than 20 open web orders pressing ‘More Web Orders’ will then download the next 20 open orders to the list. Additionally, once Web Orders has been opened the first time in the day, it will check for Web Orders automatically for you in the background, every 5 minutes. If it finds an order, it will tell you. If you restart your computer, you will need to click the Web Orders button again the first time to restart the automatic web order download process again. If you are using the Multiple Web Stores feature, pressing this button will retrieve orders from all web stores which this store has been configured to process orders for. For more information, please see section 4.9. Apply Date Range By default when you open Web Orders the Apply date Range option is unchecked and will download the 20 latest orders from your web store. Pressing More Web orders will then download the next 20 open orders from Shopify. Using the Apply Date Range option you can grab the open orders for a specific date. This will use the From Date and To Date to determine what to download and will grab any order created between 00:00 on the From Date up to 23:59 on the To Date. To Apply a Date Range check the Apply Date Range checkbox and enter the dates followed by pressing ‘Get Web Orders’. This will refresh the web orders list to show any open orders between these dates. Please note the date range settings are saved so when you exit Web Orders and reopen it will apply the previously set date range, if on the next open you want it to grab All open orders ensure before closing the Web Orders box you uncheck the Apply Date Range option.
title: Get Web Orders
description:
Pressing this button will retrieve all “Open” web orders in groups of 20 from your Shopify web store, where a payment has either been “Authorised” or “Captured”.

The application will automatically connect to Shopify and download orders when the Web Orders button is pressed in the POS, so there is no need to click the Web Orders button and then immediately click the Get Web Orders button.


If you have more than 20 open web orders pressing ‘More Web Orders’ will then download the next 20 open orders to the list.


Additionally, once Web Orders has been opened the first time in the day, it will check for Web Orders automatically for you in the background, every 5 minutes. If it finds an order, it will tell you.

 

If you restart your computer, you will need to click the Web Orders button again the first time to restart the automatic web order download process again.


If you are using the Multiple Web Stores feature, pressing this button will retrieve orders from all web stores which this store has been configured to process orders for. For more information, please see section 4.9.


Apply Date Range

By default when you open Web Orders the Apply date Range option is unchecked and will download the 20 latest orders from your web store. Pressing More Web orders will then download the next 20 open orders from Shopify.


Using the Apply Date Range option you can grab the open orders for a specific date. This will use the From Date and To Date to determine what to download and will grab any order created between 00:00 on the From Date up to 23:59 on the To Date. To Apply a Date Range check the Apply Date Range checkbox and enter the dates followed by pressing ‘Get Web Orders’. This will refresh the web orders list to show any open orders between these dates.

 

Please note the date range settings are saved so when you exit Web Orders and reopen it will apply the previously set date range, if on the next open you want it to grab All open orders ensure before closing the Web Orders box you uncheck the Apply Date Range option.

text: Pressing this button with a web order selected in the list will print a picking list to the OPOS printer defined for the installed register. This can then be used by the cashier to go and find the products they need to dispatch. If the user wants to print the picking list to a Windows Printer instead, simply check the Windows Printer box and choose the printer they want to print to. Once the button has been pressed, the Status column of the Web Orders list will change to say “Picking” to indicate that someone is already picking the goods.
title: Print Pick List
description:
Pressing this button with a web order selected in the list will print a picking list to the OPOS printer defined for the installed register. This can then be used by the cashier to go and find the products they need to dispatch.


If the user wants to print the picking list to a Windows Printer instead, simply check the Windows Printer box and choose the printer they want to print to.


Once the button has been pressed, the Status column of the Web Orders list will change to say

“Picking” to indicate that someone is already picking the goods.

text: Pressing the Complete Order button will load the Web Order you have selected into the POS transaction screen. RMSify does not actually complete the order in Shopify until it has been tendered through the POS against the defined Web Tender.
title: Complete Order
description:
Pressing the Complete Order button will load the Web Order you have selected into the POS transaction screen.

 

RMSify does not actually complete the order in Shopify until it has been tendered through the POS against the defined Web Tender.

text: RMSify has the ability to Quickly grab and process a single Shopify Order by using the RMSify Quick process button which you will see on the POS as below: Pressing the RMSify Quick Process will show an input screen where you can enter in the Shopify Order Number: Once the order number has been entered pressing 'OK' will open the normal RMSify Web Orders screen with only the single order in the list. From here you can use the normal Processing options to load the order into the POS for processing.
title: RMSify Quick Process
description:
RMSify has the ability to Quickly grab and process a single Shopify Order by using the RMSify Quick process button which you will see on the POS as below:

 

Pressing the RMSify Quick Process will show an input screen where you can enter in the Shopify Order Number:


Once the order number has been entered pressing 'OK' will open the normal RMSify Web Orders screen with only the single order in the list.

 

From here you can use the normal Processing options to load the order into the POS for processing.

text: All configuration is completed through the Sync application. This is the application that is launched when you select Start > All Programs > Retail Technology Ltd > RMSify. Alternatively, it can be launched from Headquarters or Store Operations Manager through the menu Utilities > Addins > RMSify. Initial configuration is performed through the installation wizard which takes you through the same configuration screens described in further articles, but in a more structured way. The wizard only appears on first launch. There are rules as to where you can edit the configuration, and these work in line with the supported topologies described in the Introduction. Standard Headquarters – All configuration is performed in the Headquarters database. Changes to the configuration are transmitted to the processing store through a Worksheet 51. You will not be able to open the Sync application at the processing store. Store Only Headquarters – Once the wizard is run and you have told it you are syncing from the processing store, all configuration will need to be performed at the processing store. If you want to change back to a Standard Headquarters topology, you launch the application at Headquarters and make the change there. Single Store – The configuration can be run on any computer which has RMSify installed. To access the configuration settings, click Options > Settings from the RMSify menus. Any machine which is going to run the Web Orders tool MUST have the Sync application launched once before the Web Orders “Custom POS Button” will work. Any change made in RMSify in a Headquarters database will be automatically transmitted to stores through a Worksheet 51.
title: Configuration Overview
description:
All configuration is completed through the Sync application. This is the application that is launched when you select Start > All Programs > Retail Technology Ltd > RMSify. Alternatively, it can be launched from Headquarters or Store Operations Manager through the menu Utilities > Addins > RMSify.


Initial configuration is performed through the installation wizard which takes you through the same configuration screens described in further articles, but in a more structured way. The wizard only appears on first launch.


There are rules as to where you can edit the configuration, and these work in line with the supported topologies described in the Introduction.


Standard Headquarters – All configuration is performed in the Headquarters database. Changes to the configuration are transmitted to the processing store through a Worksheet 51. You will not be able to open the Sync application at the processing store.


Store Only Headquarters – Once the wizard is run and you have told it you are syncing from the processing store, all configuration will need to be performed at the processing store. If you want to change back to a Standard Headquarters topology, you launch the application at Headquarters and make the change there.


Single Store – The configuration can be run on any computer which has RMSify installed. 


To access the configuration settings, click Options > Settings from the RMSify menus.

 

 

 

Any machine which is going to run the Web Orders tool MUST have the Sync application launched once before the Web Orders “Custom POS Button” will work.


Any change made in RMSify in a Headquarters database will be automatically transmitted to stores through a Worksheet 51.

text: If you are tracking your inventory or stock levels with your Shopify store (Please see the Rules section for details) you need to synchronise the data on a regular basis. We advise you schedule the stock to be updated automatically (see below) however you can update it manually at any time by right-clicking the RMSify icon in the bottom right hand corner by the clock, and clicking “Update Stock Quantities” If you are using the Multiple Web Stores feature, it will update the stock quantities for each defined web store, one at a time. In order to maintain accurate stock levels, its important that these are updated as frequently as possible and appropriate for your business. RMSify can perform this task for you automatically. Click Tools followed by Scheduled Stock Update. RMSify uses a Windows Scheduled Task to do this You can choose whether or not you want to make use of this feature through the Enable check box. Checked means it will run, unchecked means it will not. You can choose how often it is repeated too. By default it is selected as Daily, which means it will run the stock update at midnight every day. If you were to choose a different option, it would run every n minutes throughout the day. If you are using the Multiple Web Stores feature, it will update the stock quantities for each defined web store, one at a time. If you wish to set up more advanced settings, you can edit the properties of the relevant Windows Scheduled Task. K3 does not support the execution and advanced configuration of scheduled tasks as this is a core windows feature. For more help in configuring a scheduled task please contact your support partner.
title: Stock Sync
description:
If you are tracking your inventory or stock levels with your Shopify store (Please see the Rules section for details) you need to synchronise the data on a regular basis. We advise you schedule the stock to be updated automatically (see below) however you can update it manually at any time by right-clicking the RMSify icon in the bottom right hand corner by the clock, and clicking “Update Stock Quantities”

If you are using the Multiple Web Stores feature, it will update the stock quantities for each defined web store, one at a time. 


In order to maintain accurate stock levels, its important that these are updated as frequently as possible and appropriate for your business. RMSify can perform this task for you automatically. Click Tools followed by Scheduled Stock Update. RMSify uses a Windows Scheduled Task to do this

 

You can choose whether or not you want to make use of this feature through the Enable check box. Checked means it will run, unchecked means it will not.


You can choose how often it is repeated too. By default it is selected as Daily, which means it will run the stock update at midnight every day. If you were to choose a different option, it would run every n minutes throughout the day.

If you are using the Multiple Web Stores feature, it will update the stock quantities for each defined web store, one at a time.


If you wish to set up more advanced settings, you can edit the properties of the relevant Windows Scheduled Task.


K3 does not support the execution and advanced configuration of scheduled tasks as this is a core windows                    feature. For more help in configuring a scheduled task please contact your support partner.
